Description: Rim and body fragment of large pottery hemispherical bowl, made up of three joining sherds; black glazed inside with three bands of added white-red-white stripes; outside, light beige-grey slip; glaze differentially fired, black in upper part and orange in lower: at base, rays, below two animal friezes, separated by a metopal band of solid squares and crosses between broad bands of glaze (without additional colour). Lower frieze, deer grazing to right; upper frieze, lion to right; thick filling ornament. Coarse orange-red (5YR 6/5) clay with medium quartz sand inclusions, some lime and mica.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Schaus in CVA Philadelphia likens Histria IV 79, pl. 8 and by extension the clay analysis of that sherd. It has no connection whatsoever with this piece and is presumably an error. To check analysed piece (Dupont).

Traces of plaster at left broken edge. Marked inside in pencil 'N' and '80' (the '8' lying on its side). The smallest of the three joining fragments bears the inventory number E147.58 in ink and in pencil 'XXXI' and is assigned a provenance of Tell Dafana in the museum registers. Published in G. Schaus, CVA Philadelphia, The University Museum (2) pl. 4.6. Schaus (p. 14) notes that R.M. Cook considers a fragment now in Manchester to be by the same hand and possibly joining on the left of the Philadelphia piece. This fragment was transferred from the School of Art to the Manchester Museum but could not be located at Schaus' request.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.117)
